fasper.base
Class ActivationDescriptor

java.lang.Object
  fasper.base.ActivationDescriptor

public class ActivationDescriptor
extends Object

Describes ParserActivation inherited classes. The role of this class is to keep together all elements needed to
get a new instance of a class based on it's name, it's arguments
types and their values. Reflection mechanism is used to build such instances.
This class is used (created) in two places : fasper.base.TestActivation and in fasper.Factory.

See Also:
Factory, TestActivation

Constructor Detail

ActivationDescriptor

public ActivationDescriptor(String _name,
                            String[] _args,
                            Object[] _values)
Creates a new descriptor for the given class. First parameter should be a java.lang.String and represent the source file name.

Parameters:
_name - String name of the class decribed by this descriptor (full path is required eg. woo.test.WooActivation)
_args - String[] type names of the args used in class constructor (full path is required eg java.lang.String)
_values - Object[] values of the args of the constructor
Method Detail

getName

public String getName()
Returns target class name.

Returns:
Returns the name of the class.

getArgs

public String[] getArgs()
Returns args types of the target class constructor. Strings are full path type names eg java.lang.String

Returns:
Returns an array of arguments types.

getValues

public Object[] getValues()
Returns the values for the constructor's arguments.

Returns:
Returns values for the constructr's arguments

setValues

public void setValues(Object[] values)
Sets the values for the constructor's arguments. This is usefull when you want to reuse a descriptor and just change the constructors arguments.

Parameters:
values -

toZString

public String toZString()
Converts this descriptor to the z-file format of the descripor. For example: 
 dutActivationClass woo.test.WooActivation
 argTypeAndValue java.lang.String #"test.e"#

Returns:
Returns the string as it appears in z-file.
